These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair was dressed in full winter cycling gear. He was confident despite the cold. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’

The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 metres up. This was no problem for the car, but Alistair’s first couple of miles had a 25 per cent incline, so he had a tough start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sprinted away on his bike, heading for a track going straight up the hill and then across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny jumped in the car and was soon on the road. The next time the brothers would see each other would be at the finish line. The only question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s early confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first obstacle. A giant tractor came out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he complained to the cameraman in the back of his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s all because of this farmer!’ After tense moments, the tractor was gone, and Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been there since before cars were invented, and the roads are not made for speed. Jonny tried to get through a very narrow corner. The car slowed to a crawl, then passed through a stream on the road. Once clear of the last village, the car was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was.

As Jonny sped through the final straight to Fleet Moss, Alistair was flying across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping… and then a squeal of brakes as he reached the line. Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the waiting crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, the car pulled up and Jonny stepped out. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel separate from the outside world. The quiet helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my lifelong coach, taught me early on that this was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The 2006 defeat wasn’t so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer beat me easily, more easily than if I’d believed in myself more. But losing in 2007 left me very upset. I knew I could have done better, and it wasn’t my ability that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and waste it. Toni, a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. But I was so upset that he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my grief, but he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; that my mindset would not fail me this time. The best sign was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid them from mentioning it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. Until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

Text: 'A young, idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa in April 1957 and soon wrote home, saying, ‘I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood.’ She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. Her name was Jane Goodall. In 1963, Britain’s National Geographical Society made Jane Goodall famous with articles and TV documentaries about her chimpanzee research. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children’s books and the 1971 bestseller In the Shadow of Man, translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. Ironically, her fame might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles, interviews, and books tell her life story, but they often focus on her adventurous spirit or her role as a feminist, rather than her scientific work. These images can undervalue her true contributions. Based on the number of references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading pioneer in her field and the world’s top zoologist. Her main achievement is simple: she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before Goodall, we didn’t know chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We didn’t realize they shared emotions with humans or had social systems like ours. We wouldn’t have believed that chimpanzee communities had different cultural traditions. Her book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work in this area, like an encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe, Nigeria, is called ‘one of the Western world’s great scientific achievements’ by biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives. Even as a child, there were signs of who Jane Goodall would become. The clearest sign was in 1939, when she was five. One autumn day, Jane disappeared. The police, neighbors, and family searched for her. After a frantic search, she reappeared with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked where she had been. Jane said she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to find out. This could be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.'

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me in the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.’ Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Lots of actors, some very famous, think they can do funny voices and, actually, many of them probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it than that. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a standard acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky enough to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound enthusiastic about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheery. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a huge difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists put them together.’ She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural ability. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone considering a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more realistic jobs, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, after a typical cartoonist’s childhood (loving comic strips, contributing to school publications, being known as ‘the kid who draws’), I studied graphic design in college. After graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was earning enough to support myself. You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical barriers are low, but it’s still a tough job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t turn down work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything. But what about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are mostly gone. Today, cartooning is more like running a business – you have to create and sell your work. The more comfortable you are with this, the better you’ll do. I’ve seen cartoonists with average talent and great business skills do better than artistic geniuses. It surprises me how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they’ve never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won’t let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, just draw a ‘c’ for ‘copyright’, put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it’s more likely no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it’s not a disaster – it could be a lucky break!'

Text: Twenty years ago, I was moving house and clearing out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate getting rid of things, so why did I want to throw it away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to leave it there when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. In the years that followed, I often felt sorry for what I’d done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. That’s how I felt when I read the email from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He said, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell it back to me at a fair price. I almost cried with happiness. I had forgotten my dad’s habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I couldn’t make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t need to play well to be a rock star. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Picking it up again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the need to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered where to go, even though I couldn’t draw a diagram of the chords. My fingertips felt the pain of holding down the strings. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument, so I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others like me who want to play again. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

Text: 'Recently, there has been a lot of discussion about sleep. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one talking about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, who I interviewed many of, know that sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social health. It’s good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven’t heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, cutting off the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or ‘Rapid Eye Movement’ sleep, the stage with the most dreams. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years dreaming. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. But it wasn’t that simple. Later research didn’t support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams matter. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than others. He concluded that using dreams increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with dreams, as films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don’t all people – like teachers, software designers, and politicians – need to think creatively? Dreams, according to Stickgold, help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new patterns. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ‘ignore the obvious and put together things that make a kind of unexpected sense ... This is what creativity is,’ says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can hardly keep up. I don’t know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn’t just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. In her studio, which has a beautiful sea view, you see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a pioneer in the copyist art movement, able to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist paintings and 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Surprisingly, she doesn't keep any of her own work. 'As soon as I finish them, they go,' she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes think they are originals. While the originals are worth millions, her reproductions sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie doesn't usually reveal her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but status is also important. One celebrity likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. 'Many famous people pretend my copies are originals,' she says. 'That's their choice.' Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie's copy. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her reproductions look as real as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have done it, she has never been tempted. People who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie isn't rich and has had hard times, but her situation is better now, and she doesn't want to risk her reputation. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was good training for her current work and gave her a love for plants, but it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad she found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw accurately. She also says she has studied a lot to do what she does. Her skills allow her to do anything from drawing plants to copying 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie says people often think modern art is easy, like child's play. But impressionists painted quickly and freely, yet were also very careful. This combination is hard to master. Given her talent, it's surprising Susie doesn't create her own art. Isn't art about self-expression? And could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked like photos – okay, but not special. Susie is a perfectionist.'

During her racing days, nothing was more important to Ellen MacArthur than the sea, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a non-stop, solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat Kingfisher. It was her home and workplace for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned everything, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly showed her stock of freeze-dried food, the small gas stove, and the neatly organized medical supplies. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think about how humans take what they want and move on. When I visited Ellen’s office, she had just finished a conference call. She explained why we must act now to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways not to use them up." Initially, her message was to use less, but she realized there was another way to see things. Now she focuses on re-using, like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. The current situation is something I can't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is different. It’s about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It is part of who I am. You are connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. My new message is not as simple as saying: 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I’ve ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to inspire them to go outside and try new challenges. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – there's still a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul says, 'This isn't about me wanting fame through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided, why not now? We regularly check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more exciting the record, the more interest it gets. This creates a problem for Jordan. People might say that achieving records is more important than enjoying the adventure, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and go to the gym.'

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they’re not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won’t know who he is. I’ve just started a music degree, but even my classmates don’t know much about classical music. If you don’t know the composers, you probably don’t own their music. The statistics are not encouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I’m a musician and play in an orchestra, I’m not a big classical music fan. I like many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we can’t focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more interesting to us than long classical pieces without lyrics. Classical music is powerful, but it doesn’t deal with issues that matter to teenagers. The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why people like classical concerts more as they get older, but I know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are eager to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They like classical music when they perform, but it’s not their first choice for listening. Playing and listening to music have become separate activities. When we want to relax, we choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to herself. Her mother, who was getting out of the car too, didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. Lively, probably, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle," she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, to her delight. Focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, a breeze brushing her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian who has become famous for his music. He started playing the guitar at six and writing songs at seven. However, he was also very interested in swimming and surfing. When he was 13, he posted some videos online of himself singing at a school concert. These videos became very popular, and people wanted to see more. Cody recorded more videos at home and shared them online, receiving a lot of positive feedback.

Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches. But when record labels showed interest in him, he had to make a difficult decision: continue swimming in Australia or move to the US to pursue a music career. At a young age, Cody chose to take the risk and move with his family to the US. This decision surprised many people because Cody was known as a quiet and modest person.

His family supports him but stays out of the spotlight. Cody believes it's important to have supportive people around to stay grounded. He sometimes worries about how his decision affects his younger brother and sister, especially since his brother has to travel and do school on the road. However, his family reassures him of their support.

Cody's success came quickly and unexpectedly. He now travels to countries he never thought he would visit and performs for large audiences. He knows this success might not last forever, but he is grateful for the opportunities he has had.

Text: I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sunlight. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing I could do it. Not that my grandfather noticed much. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked along the half-mile of steaming black water from the wood processing factory in Milltown. With fragile ice on both sides, the dark open patch was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. A boy I didn’t know. I frowned. Unbelievably, he was trying to balance on an ice shelf along the water warmed by the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and reached for my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there – a silver chain my famous grandfather once brought back from South America. Better than having a famous grandfather is having this chain, which only he, my mom, and I know about. Plus, I have the diary he kept on that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read bits of it before I sleep. I patted the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled at me as I grabbed a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway, almost bumping into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going, anyway?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that obvious. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his words hurt like he wanted them to. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself at the moment,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’d always been that way. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he showed me photos of him in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty expedition medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. And yet, a part of me still wants to stay devoted to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep it up, even on these cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Text: Mum caught Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before, and it was not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. A river dominated the scene; it was not a river she recognized and maybe not even a real one, just a fantasy river. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It's got a name." There was something in her voice—too casual, too detached—that showed her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others make sense of them. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it—for him to be so specific. Maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I suppose you can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to every person who asks." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted her, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he'd have to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, having any influence over someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have cut the carpet by itself. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't mean to damage the carpet. I didn't wake up thinking, 'Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.' It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm very unlucky that way. What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! It's small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it. I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I always loved her cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for years. I don't mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to 'think outside the box'. And that's exactly what I was doing!'

The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly ‘borrow’ things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' perspective, not a human one, which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We developed a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because it was sewn on every morning. The lead actor’s trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully conveyed the magic of the books.

Text: Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the "can-you-get-me-free-tickets-to-your-dad’s-concerts?" ‘Everything’s going to be fine,’ I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. To leave my old life on the road and with tour tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet real kids for a change. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so normal. I walk into the school’s main office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule please,’ I tell the school secretary. ‘Name?’ She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. ‘Desert McGraw.’ ‘Desirée?’ she asks, leaning closer. ‘Desert,’ I repeat. The secretary seems confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types ‘McGraw’ on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One second, it’s printing,’ the secretary says. She hands me the schedule. English Literature, first period. Cool, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, so I wouldn’t look lost. When I get to the door, I hear the teacher taking roll. ‘Aurelio Gonzalez.’ ‘Here.’ She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look over my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher pauses. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says. ‘Here.’ The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she gives us time to socialize! All teachers should do this. ‘So why’d you move here?’ my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? ‘We need a change, Desert,’ he said, ‘and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.’ Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they pick South Beach Sounds, a studio near the sand? ‘My dad had to relocate,’ I tell her. Yes, lies work better. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say, playing with my backpack zipper. ‘Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.’ And she doesn’t seem to care. Excellent.

Text: 'Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being an American teenager is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and stay unnoticed, because being average is not enough. Not being ambitious is seen as laziness. Many adults forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life,’ says teenager Kristen Loose. Despite these pressures being normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist, often spread by the media. You know the stereotypes: lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, it is not fair to label the whole generation this way. ‘Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV and using our phones,’ Loose says. She believes this is mostly wrong. She admits to keeping her phone close most of the day, but not just for fun. It is a tool that helps teens and those responsible for them. Students are expected to have access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can now do their work anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities now need attention all day, adding to the stress of busy teens. Many teenagers start their day around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to do it all again the next day, often with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teens get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are so tired. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteer work. ‘People think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests,’ Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen says her favorite time of the week is when she volunteers. ‘I love helping others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community each week.’ In 20 years, who knows what the stereotype for teenagers will be, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be another generation of students making a big impact, even before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project with a twist: it’s part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These happen when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, inflates the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some run and track it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There is quiet and a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappears. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ says the group’s leader, who notes they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is becoming familiar with this landscape.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to others.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. It happened by chance when she helped her younger brother with a science project about dinosaurs. She found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, which fascinated her. Chloe decided then that she wanted to pursue this field. 

Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time, so I asked Chloe about the support she received. She recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. Chloe was nervous at first, worried he might find her annoying. However, he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel more comfortable.

I asked Chloe about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. She admits that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists in films misleading, often showing them as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks. These films do not accurately represent their daily work.

Chloe explains that her job is varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. Communicating scientific findings to the public is also important to her, especially to young people. She believes it's crucial to clear up misunderstandings about science and inspire interest in the natural world.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she advised on the accuracy of the dinosaurs shown. She praises the makers for their knowledge and says she mostly checked that the dinosaurs depicted lived in the same time period. The documentary attracted audiences of all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new, realistic way.

I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us. She thinks they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us there is still much to learn. Palaeontology, she says, is like a form of time travel.

Text: "I'm going to say this once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not 'there yet,' even as you keep asking 'Are we there yet?' The truth is, once you arrive, it's not 'there' anymore; it's 'here.' So, if you think you might be 'there,' you should ask 'Are we here yet?' And no one wants to be 'there' more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, mum or dad is there to give out snacks, change the radio, and keep everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space and we're fighting. The driver and co-pilot separate us, telling Tim to stay in his seat. This calms things down for a while. The scenery continues to pass by. Then, as I'm trying to read, I feel a breeze on my arm. But the window's not open. It's Tim, blowing on me from his seat. He's not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. But it makes me angry. Tim gets told off, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has developed ways to deal with us in the back seat. For example, when we ask 'Are we there yet?' he often says, 'Yes, we're here. Get out of the car.' 'But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.' 'Oh, then maybe we're not there yet.' That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally 'there' when the grown-ups get out of the car and move away from the kids who have annoyed them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you're not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope customers will love the experience and return. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for people to communicate face-to-face."

The games in their café are called 'Eurogames', known for gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved. This idea was developed further in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame by North American designer Matt Leacock, is about solving global problems together. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He recalls, "Playing it with friends was thrilling. Everyone felt good, win or lose. I wanted to create something similar."

Leacock's love for board games started in childhood. He was often disappointed by games, so he and his uncle would redesign them. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel added storytelling elements. Leacock says, "It's like an electronic game where you develop characters and the world changes."

The video game industry has helped board games become popular. Video games have made playing games normal. Ben Hogg, from a games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone plays games. More people are open to playing games now."

Video games once offered social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But as games moved online, players became physically separated. Some people missed playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, games are a way to connect in real life, and this trend is growing.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false beginnings. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. The only radio station he heard at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘With tennis, I was at a high level, but it wasn’t what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to pursue music, saying he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune did not come. He says, ‘In my artist career, I’ve often been in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he truly succeeded. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to. This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing with the charts in mind is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write number one hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write hits and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. ‘When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs,’ he says.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist.' This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. 

I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys knew him well, and even older people came to say he was 'an absolute legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, Tony explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could do it. But he always succeeded. When I praised him, he seemed uninterested and a bit sad. 

Tony says he is a reluctant celebrity. He finds it hard to be social. He understands the importance of connecting with fans but prefers doing stunts to talking about them. This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. Tony says this technology helps people like him make a living. He sometimes feels everyone is too focused on cameras and screens, but he doesn't complain. His videos allow him to earn money from what would have been just a hobby in the past.

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know two things are important to become an elite competitor: energy and the ability to overcome disappointment. These are more important than talent and help athletes keep going despite failure. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on easy obstacles but kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to reduce risks. Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's wise to be aware of dangers. Some people never feel scared, but Tony feels fear and finds a way to overcome it. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Before a new stunt, he prepares himself mentally. He knows he must stay focused to succeed.

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has completed many dangerous challenges for charity, like running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Although she already had some circus skills, she quickly found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t realize how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then came an hour of exercises, with another hour after my day practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to keep a positive attitude: if I was nervous and started shaking, so would the wire!’ The day of the actual challenge was windy, and Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she admitted afterward. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ The experience has not stopped Helen, however, from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set out in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. A serious fever left him in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or the journey home. Yet despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

Text: 'I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat. The work is very hard. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!'

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, and spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make, and I keep my colleagues happy by giving them samples! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling to buy raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety and lack of routine, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask if I get bored of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!'

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia says, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured, or that you might only work for a short time each year. But, actually, the real issue is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students start businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or her face, but you’ve probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren’t good enough to be lead singers. That’s not true – they have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! ‘What I love about my job is that when I walk into the recording studio, I never know what I’ll be asked to sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I’m often surprised by producers’ requests. I was once asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘Excellent musical abilities are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There’s often no printed music to look at. I’ll never forget my first experience of recording the background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra as well. I was terrified: I knew that if I got something wrong, it would mean recording everything again, which nobody enjoys. Recording sessions are long enough as they are.’ ‘One of my favourite jobs is doing recordings for songwriters. Less experienced writers don’t always understand which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it.’'

Text: Julie Deane started with only basic fashion knowledge and created a successful business with her 'satchels' - traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with celebrities. Before choosing satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning, instead of going with her first idea. Once she decided, not everyone agreed with her. Julie says, 'Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.' She involved her family from the start, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design came from children's storybooks. Although Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they have been important to her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest has continued to grow, as has the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community for ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a challenging time when another company copied Julie's design to sell similar products. As a result, she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people love working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie loved cycling and bought a special racing bike to compete. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people aren’t sure if celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it to promote themselves, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson, a singer-songwriter, grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to gain confidence. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her frustration. She posted it online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from across Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. But Joss convinced her, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a fantastic evening. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times rather than happy ones because she has more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes fans like her songs, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents had lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about what needed to be done. But Harry promised he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people now lived along that coast. On the first morning, the only other living creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far. I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize.
