Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you’ve ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. His favorite temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned about surviving in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. ‘I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.’ He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. ‘I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had coral people, elephant people, chimpanzee people. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.’ The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. ‘It is certainly easier to film today. If you shot something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.’ ‘My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.’ Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy job. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very difficult. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. ‘We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. This meant swimming in very cold water and facing frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, planning an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers are confident and driven people, and they need to be. This time, there is much more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole, measuring the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and he knows the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this job. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into blizzards with few clothes. His father shared a love of icy adventures, and Pen had unusual physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he’s at home: ‘He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic.’ For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horseback compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. ‘It’s much harder to be away from them this time,’ he admits. ‘They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in how I said goodbye. I told my son, “You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.” He took it seriously, but it was too much pressure. It was well-meaning but unfair.’ For similar reasons, he plans to have little contact with them while in the Arctic. ‘If you call them, you remind them how far away you are.’ He is spending his last days before leaving preparing his equipment carefully. ‘Out on the ice, you can’t fix things easily,’ he says. With him will be Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and the expedition photographer, Martin Hartley. They will have a support team of six flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for someone like him, says Pen, and he has other worries too. ‘I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I haven’t trained as much as I’d like.’ Why? ‘Organisational tasks always seem more urgent. So I’m almost afraid of what I’ll ask of myself.’ Pen believes his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge that inspired past explorers. ‘Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal,’ he admits, ‘and not very useful to others. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re trying to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it,’ he says. ‘Our skills, which seemed strange and not needed, are now very important. Suddenly, we’re useful again.’

Text: I had a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. These activities were great, but I missed having a competitive goal. I wanted to stay in shape in case I wanted to compete in the Olympics again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I entered, I would want to win. Would Ben be the best partner to win? Probably not. But being an underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to do the race anyway and had found the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take work. I also had to consider the loss of earnings from being away. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete. It's nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I could talk about something new: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but straightforward. I trained almost every day, but the program was set, with doctors and dieticians. I was worried about people's reactions to me racing with a TV presenter. I worried it would look like I just wanted to be on TV. My concerns disappeared during our preparations. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and a year on a deserted island. But he couldn't row. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

Text: 'Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I was feeling restless. I dreamed of Arctic landscapes, cold and empty, maybe because of the noise and crowds in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to over 100. Recently, they took over a second place – the 'wilderness farm’, which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away. November 6, London On my flight, I look at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies; I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the page down and look out of the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of flowers and leaves. But I think I see the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing. November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forest – thin trees covered in snow – stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am barely inside when I’m given boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes very loud by the time I reach the dogsheds. Three people are running back and forth, harnessing the huskies to sleds. The dogs are very excited, pulling hard on the ropes. I can hardly hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light. November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but not before a tough questioning about what I bring to the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become very difficult in freezing conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by very eager huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’'

On that day, as Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after a bike accident during training. Radcliffe says the achievement never really felt real to her. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but at the time, it just felt like what she was meant to do. Her team had a motto: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried she might not keep up the pace and could drop out. Hartmann was upset by this, but he understood why someone might think it was risky to start so fast. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the rest in 2 minutes 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run quicker than that.’ The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would come close to that time soon, but Radcliffe thought she could do it again next year. Unfortunately, that didn't happen. After the race, people wondered how she, with her awkward running style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her for weeks, helping her handle the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, ‘I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could take that level of pain. She would push me to work so deeply into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward.’ Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to her training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, ‘Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no time for a break; she wanted a two-hour session right away. Hartmann gave so much time to Radcliffe that other athletes became resentful. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has broken her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany might do it. Maybe it's because people race each other more than themselves.’ What does she mean? ‘That mental way of never relaxing, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it. I never thought, “I can relax now,” it was always: “keep pushing as hard as you can.” Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She never ran as fast again, but she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

Text: 'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I didn't know how viewers and the press would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this, but I was still worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I needn't have worried. The show's success led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, with travel and exploration. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest in the series, where you travel the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These people have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was left out. 'Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?' I could imagine people asking. But after long discussions, the TV team and I created a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book's title, I knew I wasn't claiming the recipes were 'definitive'. But I thought that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines 'perfection' as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and changing them until you have something unique. The TV series let me explore foods, people, and places I hadn't seen before, and I was excited about that. Searching for the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included being taken to a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato, and visiting a dairy farm with such low standards that we had to stop filming! While refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanning machine, and nearly burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza.'

Text: 'We were still hours away from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, went off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the bonnet. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets. Finally, he said, ‘Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,’ and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, ‘We can’t stay here forever,’ she said. The field was big, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. ‘No, we can’t stay here forever,’ I repeated, because it was safest to agree with Bea. We both got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We sat by the road and watched John get smaller as he went to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay on the grass. ‘Tell us a story,’ she said. Bea lay next to her. ‘Go on, tell us a story.’ So I told them about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and a fight over a worm. ‘That’s silly, no one understands bird language,’ Bea said. My eyes stung. ‘I do.’ But my voice wasn’t convincing. ‘Liar.’ I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. ‘Mum…?’ But she was asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind and waved at her through the windows. We followed John into a café near the road where our van was parked. ‘It’s a hotel,’ John whispered. ‘It might be expensive.’ ‘We’ll just have some tea,’ Mum said, and we sat on the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. ‘It’s like syrup in there,’ she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked at the engine. ‘It’s a miracle it got us this far,’ he said when it got dark. Mum made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn’t moving. ‘I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,’ John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we’d get home since our van needed to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.'

Lucy was at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like her: one was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, whose name Lucy didn't catch because of the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the pieces they were playing, their recent travels, and future plans. 

‘I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,’ Lucy told them. It sounded impressive, even though she didn't really want to go. She often did things she didn't want to, like concerts and competitions that took her around the world. She missed so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore and worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco instead. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she got in. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate, and her little brother Gus imagined himself at the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her repertoire. But Lucy hadn't applied; her mom had sent in the form and CD. ‘I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,’ her mom said. Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want to give her the chance to say no. Back then, Lucy thought disagreeing was the worst thing to do, so she didn't try to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward, surprised. ‘Tanglewood?’ ‘Yeah.’ ‘How old are you?’ ‘Fifteen.’ He exchanged a glance with Liesel/Louisa, who said, ‘Wow.’ Lucy hadn't meant to brag. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was showing off. ‘It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying...’ Liesel/Louisa excused herself, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. Tokyo stayed. ‘Have you ever been to Japan?’ He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were rebel music nerds. ‘Once. When I was, like, eight.’ He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared. ‘Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.’ He took her arm and led her away. ‘And don't get too friendly with the competition.’ ‘They're not the competition.’ ‘Everyone is the competition.’ Her grandfather took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, only half-listening. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, ‘You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.’ She liked being somebody, even if it made some people jealous or think she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn't earn her respect from her school friends. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

Text: "‘It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,’ said Dad. He’s hard to argue with, so I decided to see what experts say – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is a key part of modern childhood. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do – they live in it. It’s not about whether it’s good or bad – it’s how you use it that matters.’ How does our social networking compare with what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the modern version of hanging out at the youth club, as today’s parents did when they were younger, to share jokes and gossip: a kind of virtual youth club. It helps teenagers develop a sense of identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and get along with their peers. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you develop that self-identity: you can post about your favorite music or sports, discover what you enjoy, and see that other people have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He says that using social media can help if you’re shy: ‘Communicating online can be more comfortable than face-to-face, and there may be benefits from practicing social skills in a less threatening environment.’ Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how younger people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help if you’re quiet and have a special interest because they let you connect with others who like the same things. ‘If you’re one of only three people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people who like the same thing, you can still be popular, just in a different way,’ he says. Pauline White, a digital education expert, told me something interesting: ‘It’s people your age who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people, and create their own content who are really using the potential of social networks.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force: teenagers are making videos, podcasting, and blogging about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites, she says, are changing creativity. Keen photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interest. ‘This all adds to employability and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness – and you need to understand how it works to create customers. For example, if you develop a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they’re all potential customers. If you link all those networks, there’s your customer base.’ Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and share it. Collaboration is a real 21st-century skill and important for being employable in a digital age.’"

Text: 'When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province might not be the first idea. However, my parents had a different plan for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to organize a big family trip, which seemed like a teenager's worst nightmare. He and my mom kept saying, ‘Not enough people do this anymore,’ while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, ‘There are probably good reasons why!’ In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough room left for us, we started our ‘Family Great American Road Trip’. As we left our comfortable home for smaller places over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into. We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under the darkest starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway in a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way! The next day, we were up early and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that tourist town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. Climbing to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. Dodging construction traffic became normal. We laughed as we posed by the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. ‘Bear jams’, managed by park volunteers, were common when traffic stopped to let a bear cross. Our own close encounter with a bear on the road (and a worried park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the hotel we stayed in, with its problems, couldn’t ruin our excitement - a 95-year-old building with no internet or cell phone service. But in return, I saw the most amazing views. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos of our journey to look through. And I knew that for me, the best memories would be the unplanned, spontaneous moments.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. She was happy to have the best room at the college, with a kitchen and study area, and free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still keep an eye on Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten when she last saw her grandmother, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked bringing people together. Rose expected dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was sensible and mature. She knew about healthy eating, keeping fit, and getting enough sleep. But Rose wanted her independence. She wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, or go out without asking for permission every time. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen mobile phone for emergencies. Rose was thrilled. They agreed it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be overbearing. If there were issues, they would talk about it.

Rose had never been a wild child. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports were good and her exam results excellent. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time, as she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the mosaic of her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed challenging. At 13, she decided to try it. Now, the novel she started then is about to be published. When she told her former teacher, the teacher was surprised, thinking Charlotte would write a book at 30 or 40. Charlotte didn’t see why she should wait if she had a chance to be good at it.

On a winter afternoon at her publisher's office, I was surprised to see a 15-year-old girl ready to discuss her book. The book is impressive: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing, except the heroine's age, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us, but Charlotte doesn’t need any help. She is confident, intelligent, and steady, avoiding overconfidence.

Charlotte admits she is young and talks about the complex moral issues in her book. She says, ‘I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t think my understanding of the world is limited by my age, but I’m not particularly wise. I was just interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility.’

She has a theory about how teenagers are shown in books. She says there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager, and the awkward one. Reading about these types annoyed her. ‘What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who aren’t inadequate. Some writers unintentionally suggest teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-belief.’

Charlotte loves reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. ‘Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep things about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I could do it.’ She praises a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which advises that if the reader can guess what happens next, the suspense is lost.

Some might think Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, helped her get published. Her father’s connection in publishing got her book read initially. She knows she was lucky because getting a first novel read is hard, no matter the author’s age. ‘Every writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you’re on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take things for granted,’ Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping, wanted to show he knew what he was doing. He went first, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp fast and flew upwards, arms flailing. Even to us, something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle stuff. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practising turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it. If I’d tried to join the skateboarders, I’d have risked being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training centre in the US. It had a big indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students leapt, trying new tricks, and landed in pits of foam cubes – not a realistic introduction to the slopes. After practising indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the centre’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – once you’re on the real jumps, if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat section behind the jump before the slope steepens again. Land in the zone and you keep moving forward, reducing impact. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which is painful. Hence the need for speed. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain and race towards the jump. My legs would almost go into reverse as I neared the launch point, so I came down onto the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines in the centre. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was addictive. Some drills copied moves we’d make while ski-jumping, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing as you spun in space. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I was aware of the moment before take-off, and nothing more until I was lying in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as me, and for a few moments, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last long. On the final run of the day, I didn’t slow down as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed in the zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you grip the harness tightly. The ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There is a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose this: like millions of others each year, you paid to enter the theme park. It is surprising that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are such a big industry. To create the excitement and escape that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it is a real challenge. Designers must create the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe. They also need to add new features to keep visitors interested. Although people might think rollercoasters have become more extreme, many techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited to the tracks made by specialist manufacturers. I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer', said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, an engineering expert, explained that it involves quickly changing between different forces so people feel excited but safe. The goal is to create a thrilling ride without making people feel uncomfortable. To make a great ride, teams must create a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the most twists. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a theme park development director, agreed that designers need to understand what passengers want and test the rides themselves. I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect too much. Virtual reality can add something extra, like painting an old rollercoaster, but the physical ride experience will remain the most important for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already achieved a lot as a choreographer, creating works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she fits both activities into her busy schedule. ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it feels like to be in the studio taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day,’ she says. As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching young students. ‘A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they’re willing to take risks. They want success, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There may be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece. Ideally, I’d like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces – it’d help lift the mood when rehearsals are tough. But I’m always working on big productions where the music is already set by the composer and can’t be changed.’

Miranda doesn’t want to attach herself to one institution. ‘I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to adapt each time I go somewhere new, rather than do the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’

We talk about a recent documentary on ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one tries to show viewers what life is really like in a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections, and I recognized that. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but not made up for the cameras. The public underestimates the work and dedication involved in ballet.’

I ask what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything – the music, the costumes, the lighting, and the dancers – comes together. Perfection may be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong artistic choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. That’s disappointing.’

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to develop expertise in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, though I might one day be known for one thing. For now, I want to widen my horizons.’

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there’s so much to experience? That conversation gave me the idea for my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I’ve been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely new. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I got used to telling people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I’d rather explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England than talk about the latest show on TV. You’ll be able to see the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although still puzzled, he showed me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained a support boat would be with us all the time, and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim and I was nervous. I’d trained in my local pool, and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I’d hoped to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to complete this first distance, though, and was happy when I finally managed it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in; reaching a comfortable speed; stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and pleasure at completing them. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.'

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but since I started, I've traveled everywhere, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. It's a great job for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school abroad, so I often flew alone. I felt lonely and would ask flight attendants if I could help give out meals, and some let me. I remembered this when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for something new. At the interview, there were many young people, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say, focusing on my strengths and work experience, not just my love for travel. I got the job! I recommend this work to anyone because there are many benefits, but free flights aren't the main one. Most airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one's finished till everyone's finished." It's like a big family. Even though we don't see each other all the time, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to take work home. If I do get difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again!

Text: 'At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great. We do have children who miss home at the beginning of the week. Surprisingly, it's not the really young ones who feel like that the most – it's actually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can phone home after lunch. Then when they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it's a bit late to phone now, do it tomorrow. Most children are fine in a couple of days, and at the end of their week's stay, they all come up to us and thank us because they have had a great time. It's not always the children who feel lonely. We do get parents who are on the phone all the time, asking how their child is doing, which is quite unnecessary. Often their son or daughter will be busy, playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back another time. We often get a certain type of child coming, typically dressed in expensive new clothes. Children like this usually argue when we tell them to change into something more suitable, but before long they understand the reason why.'

Text: 'Rock the Planet, a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians, opened in London last year. Before that, it was in the USA for five years and won ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with only British actors was difficult. In the UK, there are more rules about how many shows young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they’ve just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, but it’s been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that were first popular in America. I met 11-year-old Jamie, one of the actors. ‘It’s great that I get paid to play,’ he said, ‘especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me how busy the young actors are. ‘We have normal school lessons each day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ And what do they think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre has special deals on tickets for schools. They loved it and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played Days, a song I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s ability and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! While the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Fortunately, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it’s worth seeing.'
